citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
***A young female zebra was observed with a small wound on her hind quarter in December 2024. The facility determined
the wound was superficial and treated it but could not determine what caused the injury. In the afternoon on January 9,
2025 employees observed a mini zebu bull attacking the same zebra. They were able to separate them but the zebra had
obtained extensive wounds. They immediately contacted the Attending Veterinarian who said he would come out that
evening but he did not show. The next morning the zebra was found dead.
Although attempts were made to provide veterinary care for the injured zebra by the facility, adequate veterinary care was
not provided prior to its death.
Appropriate veterinary care shall be provided to all animals in a timely manner. Correct from this date (February 28, 2025)
forward.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
***A female Aoudad was observed to be three legged lame, she was limping on her left forelimb. The attendant stated
that he had noted one limping but was not sure if this was the same animal. Records show the veterinarian had made a
visit to the park on January 27, 2025 visually observing all animals and treated some hoof stock for foot rot. The Program
of Veterinary Care provides instructions for treating "stone bruising" but there is no information to show the animals
condition had been observed and the information conveyed to the veterinarian.
Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being may be accomplished by someone other than the
attending veterinarian, provided that information is conveyed to the attending veterinarian in a timely manner.
Information concerning this animal shall be conveyed to the veterinarian and appropriate treatment provided.
Correct by March 2, 2025.

***The back fence at the goat enclosure on the hill in the walkthrough portion of the park is in disrepair. A new chain link
fence has been built on the outside of the wooden fence to replace it but the wooden fence has not been removed and the
boards are falling into the enclosure. The boards may contain nails or screws that could cause injury and the boards
provide a trip hazard.
All fallen boards shall be removed to protect the goats from injury. Correct by March 7, 2025.
***There is a divider fence constructed separating the goats and a donkey that is in disrepair. Due to recent rains the
fence is leaning and does not appear to be secure. There are boards that have fallen off into the pen creating a trip
hazard.
The fence shall be repaired or replaced to protect the animals from injury and maintain them securely within their
enclosures. Correct by March 15, 2025.
***The shelter in the camel enclosure has a tin panel wall that has been torn leaving sharp jagged edges that may cause
injury to the camel when rubbing or scratching along the wall. All sharp material shall be repaired or replaced to protect
the camel from injury. Correct by March 7, 2025.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Manager.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
***A young female zebra was observed with a small wound on her hind quarter in December 2024. The facility determined 
the wound was superficial and treated it but could not determine what caused the injury. In the afternoon on January 9, 
2025 employees observed a mini zebu bull attacking the same zebra. They were able to separate them but the zebra had 
obtained extensive wounds. They immediately contacted the Attending Veterinarian who said he would come out that 
evening but he did not show. The next morning the zebra was found dead.  
 
Although attempts were made to provide veterinary care for the injured zebra by the facility, adequate veterinary care was 
not provided prior to its death.  
 
Appropriate veterinary care shall be provided to all animals in a timely manner. Correct from this date (February 28, 2025) 
forward. 
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
***A female Aoudad was observed to be three legged lame, she was limping on her left forelimb. The attendant stated 
that he had noted one limping but was not sure if this was the same animal. Records show the veterinarian had made a 
visit to the park on January 27, 2025 visually observing all animals and treated some hoof stock for foot rot. The Program 
of Veterinary Care provides instructions for treating "stone bruising" but there is no information to show the animals 
condition had been observed and the information conveyed to the veterinarian. 
 
Daily observation of all animals to assess their health and well-being may be accomplished by someone other than the 
attending veterinarian, provided that information is conveyed to the attending veterinarian in a timely manner. 
 
Information concerning this animal shall be conveyed to the veterinarian and appropriate treatment provided. 
 
Correct by March 2, 2025.

3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
***The back fence at the goat enclosure on the hill in the walkthrough portion of the park is in disrepair. A new chain link 
fence has been built on the outside of the wooden fence to replace it but the wooden fence has not been removed and the 
boards are falling into the enclosure. The boards may contain nails or screws that could cause injury and the boards 
provide a trip hazard. 
 
All fallen boards shall be removed to protect the goats from injury. Correct by March 7, 2025. 
 
***There is a divider fence constructed separating the goats and a donkey that is in disrepair. Due to recent rains the 
fence is leaning and does not appear to be secure. There are boards that have fallen off into the pen creating a trip 
hazard.  
 
The fence shall be repaired or replaced to protect the animals from injury and maintain them securely within their 
enclosures. Correct by March 15, 2025. 
 
***The shelter in the camel enclosure has a tin panel wall that has been torn leaving sharp jagged edges that may cause 
injury to the camel when rubbing or scratching along the wall. All sharp material shall be repaired or replaced to protect 
the camel from injury. Correct by March 7, 2025. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the Manager.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
